Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Atomistic Simulations of Enzymatic Modulation of Long-Timescale Biomolecular Switches

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Sub-cellular signaling processes generally involve recognition and transient interactions between biomolecules and switching of conformations. These signaling processes, at times, occur over very long timescales (seconds to minutes). For the on-off signaling to take place at biologically relevant timescales (milliseconds), nature has provided enzymes to catalyze and increase the rates of these processes. One of the major challenges in computational biophysics is describing, at the atomistic detail, biomolecular events that are beyond the microsecond timescale. This project takes advantage of an accelerated molecular dynamics simulation method developed by the principle investigator (PI) to access long timescale events and fully model the enzymatic mechanism of peptidyl prolyl cis-trans isomerases (PPIases). PPIases are a class of ubiquitous enzymes that catalyze the notoriously slow cis-trans switching of the prolyl peptide bond of their protein substrates in many important signaling pathways. The goal of this CAREER project is to investigate the conformational transitions of cis-trans biomolecular switches, including the phosphorylation dependent cis-trans switches, and the associated mechanistic role of PPIases. Experiments have provided wealth of structural insights and kinetic information on PPIases, but they have not been able to provide a complete picture of the mechanism at the atomistic level. Direct observations at this level are hard to achieve with current experimental techniques. As a result, the mechanism of action of PPIases that is required for better understanding of certain sub-cellular processes has been elusive and controversial.

This CAREER project will have broad impacts in fundamental research as well as scientific training. By unraveling the atomistic details of biomolecular switching mechanisms and the accompanying protein dynamics, a better understanding of the inner workings of molecular machines at the physicochemical level will be achieved. And at a higher level, this will undoubtedly illuminate how cellular signaling takes place under normal and aberrant conditions. Also, the knowledge gained from this project will allow the PI to make testable hypotheses and to ask specific questions that can then be addressed experimentally. More importantly, this project provides an excellent opportunity to attract and train the next generation of scientists. Computational chemistry cuts across many disciplines, including chemistry, biology, physics, mathematics, and computer science, and therefore, provides an excellent tool for attracting students into the sciences. An advantage of computational chemistry in teaching is the fact that dynamic atomistic and molecular descriptions of concepts that would otherwise seem abstract can be made understandable. In addition to training undergraduate and graduate students, this project will allow the PI to expose high school students to scientific research in a safe environment and reach out to high school and middle school students through a well-established Bio-Bus outreach program at Georgia State University. This outreach program will help to raise scientific literacy amongst school-aged children and provide access to a larger audience, especially those in school districts with underrepresented minorities in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Enzymes speed up chemical reactions, allowing the reactions to occur fast enough for cells to function properly. One of the long-standing questions in biochemistry is how enzymes achieve this remarkable speedup. Enzymes and their substrates are constantly in motions, changing their conformations or shapes. Biological processes in the cell generally are dictated by the switching of the conformations of the biomolecules. Of particular interest is the role the switching of the conformations of enzymes play in catalyzing their chemical reactions.

Wet chemistry and biology experiments have provided a great deal of information about enzymes. However, some limitations in certain experimental techniques do not allow for fully understanding how enzymes catalyze their chemical reactions and what exactly the atoms are doing during catalysis. Our computational chemistry research and molecular simulations have had enormous impact on the understanding of the function of biomolecules in cellular functions. Molecular simulations using high performance computing have proven invaluable as complementary techniques to experiments in fully understanding the function of biomolecules in biology.

The overarching goal of the funded research was to fully understand the role of these conformational changes in enzymes and their substrates during the catalytic process. One of the major challenges in the field of computational molecular biophysics is describing what the atoms are doing for processes that take longer than microseconds. In addressing these challenges, the funded research, which helped to train many undergraduate students and graduate students, developed and applied theoretical and molecular simulations to study several enzymes. The funded research mainly focused on enzymes that are overexpressed in cancer and are involved in Alzheimer’s disease. These computational methodologies are fast becoming indispensable in the field of biochemistry, biophysics, and medicine. The funded research unraveled many details of how enzymes work, including details on their possible role, or lack thereof, in diseases. These studies have taken the field significantly forward and have open entirely new areas by providing testable hypothesis for experimental research.

Funding of the funded research helped to train the next generation of scientists. The funded research resulted in the training of fourteen undergraduate students, four doctoral students, five masters students - including a high school teacher, five high school and junior college students, and four postdoctoral fellows. The former students and postdoctoral associates have gone on to graduate schools, professional schools, and teaching positions. Many of the students were underrepresented minorities in science and engineering. During the funding period, products of the funded research resulted in thirty-six publications, thirty-three published articles in peer-reviewed journals and two book chapters. The results of the funded research were presented at over thirty national and international scientific conferences and universities.

In addition to training undergraduate and graduate students, K-12 students were exposed to science through a well-established Bio-Bus outreach program at Georgia State University. This outreach program helped to raise scientific literacy among school-aged children and provided access to a larger audience, especially those in school districts with underrepresented minorities in science and engineering.
